content.description: This is a good route on good rock.  There is more gear and more holds than is immediately apparent from the ground, making for a reasonably good route.  The route is not obvious from the ground, but once you start climbing it, the holds will appear.  The rock quality here is excellent.
content.protection: A small cam up under an undercling down low, then transitioning to a crack with other gear.
content.location:
This route starts just left of the

Snickers Dihedral

and rises up and left under a slight overlap of rock that goes the length of the face.  Climb up to that overlap a few feet, then use the best footholds available to slab your way up near-perfect stone.  What appears to be (I was soloing and didn't place it) an undercling cam placement will appear just as you need gear.  Continue up and left past that onto easier moves, more positive holds, and more gear where you will turn right and go up into a solid crack with gear to the summit.

content.description:
This short climb is so-so at best, mostly due to its length. Protection is poor and the climbing awkward, yet the climb is not horrible, so perhaps it deserves a star, if for no other reason that it doesn't quite deserve a bomb.

Climb up the corner to the notch (and back down- to tick it off twice?) or continue just over the top and scramble up the ridge Southward to the South summit, passing the bolted anchors to Plain Or Peanut on West face along the way.

Descend via down-climbing this route or down the SE edge of the East Slab from the South summit.
content.protection: Maybe a piece or two somewhere.
content.location: This climb is the obvious, huge, Southwest-facing corner between the peerless slabs at the Southwest end of the rock, and it climbs up to a low notch between the two main blocks.

content.description:
Scramble up to a ledge to reach a really high first bolt. You can get some cams to protect the first clip. Pull over a bulge, and be prepared to get "schooled"!  Continue straight up to the top.

There is a good #2 in a pod for an anchor as well as other bad gear. There is a small tree about 20' back from the top. It's an easy scramble around the right side of the crag and across the east face to reach the top.
content.location: It is on the North side of the West face.

content.description:
We loved this to pieces. A delightful free solo up the short, south face helped keep us from falling to pieces because of the bird nesting closures nearby. A fun romp with positive holds gains the south horn. Scramble across the slab and up the final feet of

Mounds

to stand on the summit proper and look down at

Plain or Peanut

. It is possible to set up a TR here and be thanked for teaching the kids the missing pieces this year.

Reverse the moves, which seem easier to downclimb, and prove you are an important piece to our team.
content.protection: Maybe a nut, tricam or sling the little horn.  The sweetest piece is to free up and down.
content.location: On the South face near the tree alcove, look up and ponder, you are the piece we were missing.

content.description:
Be gentle with a fragile flake past the first bolt. Mantel and stand on a rail.  A couple of thin moves lead past the last two bolts.

This would be classic if it were much longer. The view alone makes it worth a lap.
content.protection: 4 bolts and an anchor with rings.
content.location: Follow the Fern Canyon trail until you reach the saddle west of the Nebel Horn ridge.  Head NE on social trails for a hundred feet until you hit rock.  This is the obvious bolt line on the right side of the big open book.

content.description: This is a care-free romp up solid, incut edges from the bottom to the top.  The holds are not very visible from below but surprise you one after another with how large and positive they are.  This is the easiest route up Mars Block and protects reasonably from good stances.  This might even be a good beginner lead if it were not for the difficulty of setting a solid anchor up top for the belay.
content.protection: A standard light rack.  An anchor up top is a bit of a challenge to find between the flakes and cracks.
content.location: This route lies perhaps 3 meters right of the Southeast point of the Mars Block and just to the right of Almond Joy.  The route ascends a system of upward-pointing flakes that are hard to see from below into a seam to the top of the rock.

content.description: This is a short climb up broken/loose flakes with poor gear and uneven groundfall potential from the crux.  The Haas book gives this a star, but I do not know why.  The route is rated 5.8 as well, but it felt difficult to get feet into for that grade at my height and must be far harder for short folks.
content.protection: Mostly cams behind semi-detached flakes.  The route was probably initially soloed, which might be why this was not noted in detail. Gear up top can be challenging to get as well.
content.location: Almond Joy climbs a left facing system of semi-detached flakes rising upward from a bulge at the ground a few feet East of the Southeast most point of the rock.  After 25', it hits a ledge and moves slightly right out on a face and to the top.

content.description: I haven't climbed this route, but having looked at it, from top to bottom, it looks thin and sustained. The obvious line is to follow the bolts along the vertical north-facing wall, near the arÃªte at the west end of the wall. I saw an old "bail biner" at the 4th or 5th bolt, perhaps where the crux lies. The wall is rather exposed to wind from the west and north.
content.protection: This is a bolted route with 6 bolts. There is a chain hanging from the anchor, I am not sure what condition it is in.
content.location: Walk north 100 yards from the saddle at the top of Fern Canyon on a trail and down a bit under the west-facing wall of the Mars Block, around the corner to the north face. The route is apparent.
